taxi and proceeded to Katak at once.
Un arriving, I found Sharp,
the field and scattered.
was no American on CNAC's staff at the Airport at the time the
raid was on and while the planes
stopped by the police and air raid wardens.
We got all the planes
off the field and on the road,
spaced about 300 yards apart, when
the air raid alarm sounded again.
As there is practically
warning in Hongkong,
we all
scattered.
Sharp, Price and myself
and most of the Americans
got in cars and drove to
the foot of the
hills where we waited.
After about 15 minutes nothing happened,
so we decided to go back, although the alarm was still on.
We looked the situation over and decided the only place
we could hide the planes was to push them off the road onto
the
little vegetable patches along the road opposite the Airport and
camouflage them the best we could.
It required some grading and
levelling to get the planes off the road, but everybody went to
work and we pressed in as many coolies as we could.
In about two
hours we had
all the planes
camouflaged, at least the best we could
under the circumstances.
All we could do then was to wait for
darkness and hope for the best.
About this time I received a message from Dr. Kung,
ask-
ing me to get his family out of Hongkong.
I also received
several
tions in Hongkong were or might be.
I tore them all up.
We then went to work preparing the various spare parts
and supplies for evacuation.
As I was anxious to get back
to Hong-
kong to see Madame Kung,
I got PAA's mechanic, Mr. Maish, to take
me over on the PAA motor boat.
We
got out, from the shore a little
we had to return.
This was about half past one, I think.
as we got back,
the air raid alarm sounded again.
We went up to
the hangar and found that all the cars, including my taxi,
had
left.
CNAC had one truck and we loaded it as full
as possible with
Chinese personnel
who were
on the field.
I sent them
away from
the Airport.
There were to Chinese mechanics and myself left who
were unable to get
on the truck.
I told them to leave the Airport
and get into a culvert across the road from the Airport.
There
was
a big culvert on the Airport, so I decided to stay close to it and
if the raid
came over - and it appeared to be heading for the Air-
port - I would get into it.
Just then loss came by in his car and
suggested that we go over to the gateman's office at the corner of
the Airport.
It had been sandbagged all around the sides,.
so that
it offered good protection except from a direct hit.
I got 1n
with Moss and we drove over to this office at the entrance gate.
By this time two machine guns had been set up on tripods for anti-
aircraft work and were manned by Indian troops.
There
were two
English soldiers with rifles,
Including a sargeant, at the gate
and several of Mr. Moss'
staff.
Shortly after this, planes began to come over in many
groups and proceeded to fly over Hongkong and Kowloon.
There was
